DOC.HEAD: Moldavians Ask Congress to Appeal for Reason
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Moldavian delegates, worried about their ethnic brethren in Romania, asked the Soviet Congress on Wednesday to appeal for ``reason and order'' there. Ion Drutse, a well-known Moldavian poet, said the Stalinist regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu might embark on a new wave of repression against Romanians seeking greater democracy. ``It would cost him nothing to build his palace of the skulls of his subjects,'' Drutse told a reporter in the lobby of the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses. Anti-government protests began last weekend in Timisoara, a city of 350,000 people in Transylvania, western Romania. Estimates of the number of people killed by Ceausescu's security forces reach the thousands. Soviet Moldavia, a small repubic of about 4 million people, is on Romania's eastern border. Moldavians are essentially ethnic Romanians whose territory has gone back and forth, last falling into the Soviet sphere during World War II. The declaration proposed by the Moldavian legislators expresses hope that ``all problems will be solved in the framework of reason and order'' and through dialogue between the Romanian government and population, Drutse said. Moldavians said they asked the Congress leadership to put the declaration up for a vote, but it had not been done by Wednesday evening. Drutse said he believed passing the declaration could help ease tension in Romania because every ``tyrant is afraid of something.'' The Soviet Union has made no move toward intervening in its ally's affairs. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said Wednesday a ``massive flow of information'' made it hard to judge what was happening in Romania, but if reports of loss of life were confirmed, ``this is a reason for profound regret.'' Official media have taken a critical tone toward Ceausescu's Stalinist regime.
